speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: SCENE II. KING JOHN'S palace.

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Enter KING JOHN, PEMBROKE, SALISBURY, and other Lords

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Here once again we sit, once again crown'd,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And looked upon, I hope, with cheerful eyes.

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: This 'once again,' but that your highness pleased,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Was once superfluous: you were crown'd before,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: And that high royalty was ne'er pluck'd off,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: The faiths of men ne'er stained with revolt;

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Fresh expectation troubled not the land

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: With any long'd-for change or better state.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Therefore, to be possess'd with double pomp,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To guard a title that was rich before,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To gild refined gold, to paint the lily,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To throw a perfume on the violet,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To smooth the ice, or add another hue

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Unto the rainbow, or with taper-light

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To seek the beauteous eye of heaven to garnish,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Is wasteful and ridiculous excess.

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: But that your royal pleasure must be done,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: This act is as an ancient tale new told,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: And in the last repeating troublesome,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Being urged at a time unseasonable.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: In this the antique and well noted face

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Of plain old form is much disfigured;

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: And, like a shifted wind unto a sail,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: It makes the course of thoughts to fetch about,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Startles and frights consideration,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Makes sound opinion sick and truth suspected,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: For putting on so new a fashion'd robe.

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: When workmen strive to do better than well,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: They do confound their skill in covetousness;

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: And oftentimes excusing of a fault

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Doth make the fault the worse by the excuse,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: As patches set upon a little breach

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Discredit more in hiding of the fault

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Than did the fault before it was so patch'd.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To this effect, before you were new crown'd,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: We breathed our counsel: but it pleased your highness

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To overbear it, and we are all well pleased,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Since all and every part of what we would

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Doth make a stand at what your highness will.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Some reasons of this double coronation

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: I have possess'd you with and think them strong;

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And more, more strong, then lesser is my fear,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: I shall indue you with: meantime but ask

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: What you would have reform'd that is not well,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And well shall you perceive how willingly

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: I will both hear and grant you your requests.

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Then I, as one that am the tongue of these,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: To sound the purpose of all their hearts,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Both for myself and them, but, chief of all,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Your safety, for the which myself and them

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Bend their best studies, heartily request

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: The enfranchisement of Arthur; whose restraint

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Doth move the murmuring lips of discontent

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: To break into this dangerous argument,--

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: If what in rest you have in right you hold,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Why then your fears, which, as they say, attend

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: The steps of wrong, should move you to mew up

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Your tender kinsman and to choke his days

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: With barbarous ignorance and deny his youth

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: The rich advantage of good exercise?

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: That the time's enemies may not have this

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: To grace occasions, let it be our suit

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: That you have bid us ask his liberty;

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Which for our goods we do no further ask

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Than whereupon our weal, on you depending,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Counts it your weal he have his liberty.

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Enter HUBERT

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Let it be so: I do commit his youth

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: To your direction. Hubert, what news with you?

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Taking him apart

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: This is the man should do the bloody deed;

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: He show'd his warrant to a friend of mine:

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: The image of a wicked heinous fault

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Lives in his eye; that close aspect of his

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Does show the mood of a much troubled breast;

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: And I do fearfully believe 'tis done,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: What we so fear'd he had a charge to do.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: The colour of the king doth come and go

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Between his purpose and his conscience,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Like heralds 'twixt two dreadful battles set:

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: His passion is so ripe, it needs must break.

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: And when it breaks, I fear will issue thence

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: The foul corruption of a sweet child's death.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: We cannot hold mortality's strong hand:

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Good lords, although my will to give is living,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: The suit which you demand is gone and dead:

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: He tells us Arthur is deceased to-night.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Indeed we fear'd his sickness was past cure.

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Indeed we heard how near his death he was

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Before the child himself felt he was sick:

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: This must be answer'd either here or hence.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Why do you bend such solemn brows on me?

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Think you I bear the shears of destiny?

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Have I commandment on the pulse of life?

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: It is apparent foul play; and 'tis shame

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: That greatness should so grossly offer it:

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: So thrive it in your game! and so, farewell.

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Stay yet, Lord Salisbury; I'll go with thee,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: And find the inheritance of this poor child,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: His little kingdom of a forced grave.

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: That blood which owed the breadth of all this isle,

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Three foot of it doth hold: bad world the while!

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: This must not be thus borne: this will break out

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: To all our sorrows, and ere long I doubt.

speaker: PEMBROKE
text_entry: Exeunt Lords

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: They burn in indignation. I repent:

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: There is no sure foundation set on blood,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: No certain life achieved by others' death.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: A fearful eye thou hast: where is that blood

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: That I have seen inhabit in those cheeks?

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: So foul a sky clears not without a storm:

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Pour down thy weather: how goes all in France?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: From France to England. Never such a power

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: For any foreign preparation

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Was levied in the body of a land.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The copy of your speed is learn'd by them;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: For when you should be told they do prepare,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The tidings come that they are all arrived.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: O, where hath our intelligence been drunk?

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Where hath it slept? Where is my mother's care,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: That such an army could be drawn in France,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And she not hear of it?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My liege, her ear

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Is stopp'd with dust; the first of April died

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Your noble mother: and, as I hear, my lord,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Lady Constance in a frenzy died

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Three days before: but this from rumour's tongue

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: I idly heard; if true or false I know not.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Withhold thy speed, dreadful occasion!

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: O, make a league with me, till I have pleased

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: My discontented peers! What! mother dead!

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: How wildly then walks my estate in France!

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Under whose conduct came those powers of France

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: That thou for truth givest out are landed here?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Under the Dauphin.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Thou hast made me giddy

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: With these ill tidings.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Enter the BASTARD and PETER of Pomfret

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Now, what says the world

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: To your proceedings? do not seek to stuff

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: My head with more ill news, for it is full.

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: But if you be afeard to hear the worst,

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: Then let the worst unheard fall on your bead.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Bear with me cousin, for I was amazed

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Under the tide: but now I breathe again

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Aloft the flood, and can give audience

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: To any tongue, speak it of what it will.

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: How I have sped among the clergymen,

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: The sums I have collected shall express.

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: But as I travell'd hither through the land,

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: I find the people strangely fantasied;

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: Possess'd with rumours, full of idle dreams,

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: Not knowing what they fear, but full of fear:

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: And here a prophet, that I brought with me

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: From forth the streets of Pomfret, whom I found

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: With many hundreds treading on his heels;

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: To whom he sung, in rude harsh-sounding rhymes,

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: That, ere the next Ascension-day at noon,

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: Your highness should deliver up your crown.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Thou idle dreamer, wherefore didst thou so?

speaker: PETER
text_entry: Foreknowing that the truth will fall out so.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Hubert, away with him; imprison him;

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And on that day at noon whereon he says

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: I shall yield up my crown, let him be hang'd.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Deliver him to safety; and return,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: For I must use thee.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Exeunt HUBERT with PETER

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: O my gentle cousin,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Hear'st thou the news abroad, who are arrived?

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: The French, my lord; men's mouths are full of it:

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: Besides, I met Lord Bigot and Lord Salisbury,

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: With eyes as red as new-enkindled fire,

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: And others more, going to seek the grave

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: Of Arthur, who they say is kill'd to-night

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: On your suggestion.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Gentle kinsman, go,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And thrust thyself into their companies:

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: I have a way to win their loves again;

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Bring them before me.

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: I will seek them out.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Nay, but make haste; the better foot before.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: O, let me have no subject enemies,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: When adverse foreigners affright my towns

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: With dreadful pomp of stout invasion!

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Be Mercury, set feathers to thy heels,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And fly like thought from them to me again.

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: The spirit of the time shall teach me speed.

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Spoke like a sprightful noble gentleman.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Go after him; for he perhaps shall need

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Some messenger betwixt me and the peers;

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And be thou he.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: With all my heart, my liege.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: My mother dead!

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Re-enter HUBERT

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: My lord, they say five moons were seen to-night;

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Four fixed, and the fifth did whirl about

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: The other four in wondrous motion.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Five moons!

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Old men and beldams in the streets

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Do prophesy upon it dangerously:

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Young Arthur's death is common in their mouths:

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: And when they talk of him, they shake their heads

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: And whisper one another in the ear;

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: And he that speaks doth gripe the hearer's wrist,

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Whilst he that hears makes fearful action,

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: With wrinkled brows, with nods, with rolling eyes.

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: I saw a smith stand with his hammer, thus,

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: The whilst his iron did on the anvil cool,

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: With open mouth swallowing a tailor's news;

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Who, with his shears and measure in his hand,

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Standing on slippers, which his nimble haste

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Had falsely thrust upon contrary feet,

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Told of a many thousand warlike French

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: That were embattailed and rank'd in Kent:

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Another lean unwash'd artificer

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Cuts off his tale and talks of Arthur's death.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Why seek'st thou to possess me with these fears?

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Why urgest thou so oft young Arthur's death?

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Thy hand hath murder'd him: I had a mighty cause

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: To wish him dead, but thou hadst none to kill him.

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: No had, my lord! why, did you not provoke me?

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: It is the curse of kings to be attended

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: By slaves that take their humours for a warrant

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: To break within the bloody house of life,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And on the winking of authority

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: To understand a law, to know the meaning

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Of dangerous majesty, when perchance it frowns

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: More upon humour than advised respect.

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Here is your hand and seal for what I did.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: O, when the last account 'twixt heaven and earth

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Is to be made, then shall this hand and seal

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Witness against us to damnation!

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: How oft the sight of means to do ill deeds

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Make deeds ill done! Hadst not thou been by,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: A fellow by the hand of nature mark'd,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Quoted and sign'd to do a deed of shame,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: This murder had not come into my mind:

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: But taking note of thy abhorr'd aspect,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Finding thee fit for bloody villany,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Apt, liable to be employ'd in danger,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: I faintly broke with thee of Arthur's death;

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And thou, to be endeared to a king,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Made it no conscience to destroy a prince.

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: My lord--

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Hadst thou but shook thy head or made a pause

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: When I spake darkly what I purposed,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Or turn'd an eye of doubt upon my face,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: As bid me tell my tale in express words,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Deep shame had struck me dumb, made me break off,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And those thy fears might have wrought fears in me:

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: But thou didst understand me by my signs

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And didst in signs again parley with sin;

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Yea, without stop, didst let thy heart consent,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And consequently thy rude hand to act

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: The deed, which both our tongues held vile to name.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Out of my sight, and never see me more!

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: My nobles leave me; and my state is braved,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Even at my gates, with ranks of foreign powers:

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Nay, in the body of this fleshly land,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: This kingdom, this confine of blood and breath,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Hostility and civil tumult reigns

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Between my conscience and my cousin's death.

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Arm you against your other enemies,

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: I'll make a peace between your soul and you.

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Young Arthur is alive: this hand of mine

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Is yet a maiden and an innocent hand,

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Not painted with the crimson spots of blood.

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Within this bosom never enter'd yet

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: The dreadful motion of a murderous thought;

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: And you have slander'd nature in my form,

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Which, howsoever rude exteriorly,

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Is yet the cover of a fairer mind

speaker: HUBERT
text_entry: Than to be butcher of an innocent child.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Doth Arthur live? O, haste thee to the peers,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Throw this report on their incensed rage,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And make them tame to their obedience!

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Forgive the comment that my passion made

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Upon thy feature; for my rage was blind,

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: And foul imaginary eyes of blood

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Presented thee more hideous than thou art.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: O, answer not, but to my closet bring

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: The angry lords with all expedient haste.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: I conjure thee but slowly; run more fast.

speaker: KING JOHN
text_entry: Exeunt
